What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a broader knowledge of American presidential election history between the middle of the 20th century and modern day; a more nuanced understanding of the relationship between the media, the electorate, and candidates; and a stronger understanding of how the media landscape has changed over the last half century.

knowledge: history of late 20th century America, how presidential campaigns work, ins and outs of political journalism
skills: analyzing trends of presidential media
insights: the media plays a HUGE role in politics
I learned a lot about the way that the media's role in campaigns has evolved! The course is very well organized to communicate this.
I learned about the changing face of presidential campaign coverage since 1960, as well as some of the patterns in how it works today.
The history of journalism and campaigns!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The syllabus was very well crafted with fascinating readings that provided a great basis for discussion but were also just a pleasure to read; the course developed very naturally in terms of week-to-week progression and building on knowledge from previous weeks; class discussions were always lively and insightful; and the guest speakers Professor Shapiro brought in were all wonderful. 

Weaknesses: cannot think of a single one!

strengths: fantastic reading list, very relevant syllabus, great guest lecturers
weaknesses: some classes felt a little repetitive
areas of improvement: n/a
Very interesting discussions and readings. I don't have much negative to say!

Strengths: Professor Shapiro is very nice, personable, and knowledgable about the topic of the seminar. Hearing about his experiences definitely adds to the course, and in my experience, he was pretty accessible to meet with on Zoom outside of class. The readings are generally interesting as well, and the workload is pretty straightforward (participation, a brief reading response every week, midterm paper, final paper). There were also very cool guest speakersmostly journalists, but also one political campaign operativewho added their valuable perspectives to class from time to time and gave a chance for us to engage with the class material in a more "interactive" sort of way. Weaknesses: The final paper felt a little bit hard to approach because the focus was supposed to be on the 2020 Democratic primary, which wasn't discussed nearly as much in class or in the readings as were the dynamics from 2016 or the 2020 general election. I understand the idea of applying our knowledge to something that we hadn't discussed at length, but it was kind of hard to rely on memory to choose and pursue a topic.
No weakness, AMAZING COURSE, 100% take if you can get it

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: all succeeded
The Professor did a great job with the virtual platform!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely, 100% yes! If you are interested in politics, journalism, democracy, or anything in between, this course is for you. Come for the amazing reading list and course topic, and stay for Professor Shapiro's witty commentary, relevant stories from his time covering elections, and the wonderful class discussion.
absolutely
I definitely would!
Yes, if you have any interest in American electoral politics or journalism/news/media.

100% would recommend, but it is a very specific kind of vibe. Most weeks you read at least half of a book, but discussion in seminar was pretty freeform, with Professor Shapiro often telling stories or going off on tangents. Professor Shapiro is an absolute delight, highly recommend going to his office hours just to chat with him.
Yes! One of the best courses at Yale!

YES of course!! The course was so wonderful and the Professor was extremely accessible during office hours! I learned so much about the history of campaigns and the media! I feel like what I learned is what I will use in my everyday life!! Amazing amazing course!!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: with guest lectures
Virtual live seminar!
